1484593017533128705.text: 3/ Key questions in conspiracy include who entered an agreement & what they intended to do. This memo doesn't prove Trump entered a conspiracy - he never entered the order. Did he reject it as illegal? Was he prevented? Investigation to understand what happened here is essential.

1484592516196405250.text: 2/ This order wasn't written by a group of constitutional law scholars. There are real issues here & the courts *should* have promptly invalidated it, but of course that takes time. This memo, however, is key evidence of a conspiracy DOJ should be investigating.

1463582142320058368.text: Felony murder is a killing that occurs during the commission of another felony - here prosecutors charged aggravated assault & false imprisonment. There is no need to prove intent as long as all the elements of the underlying crime are proven, along with the death.

1463581806641524742.text: Malice murder is intentional murder - the intent can be either direct or implied from killing without provocation in a manner that demonstrates a “malignant heart.”

1463581325949120517.text: Murder in Georgia includes both malice murder & felony murder and carries a potential sentence of life in prison.

1463578694111436801.text: And Bryant is found guilty of  3 counts of felony murder

1463578236336680973.text: Greg McMichael is found not guilty of malice murder but guilty of 4 counts of felony murder, which carries essentially the same potential penalty.

1458617299435458568.text: @RexHuppke 🙏🏼 But honestly, I just cut the self defense statute up into pieces and put it into tweets. This is just the law.

1458602938637639681.text: 9/ I know there are a lot of take on where this trial is going, but honestly, you don't really know until the jury comes back. That's fairly obvious, but worth the reminder here.

1458602695380590597.text: 8/ Today, the judge made a big point of telling the jury that he, not the lawyers, would tell them what the law is before they deliberate. It will be up to them to decide the factual issues that determine whether Rittenhouse is entitled to the defense.

1458601959561252870.text: 7/ Wisconsin caselaw provides: The reasonableness of a person's belief..is judged from the position of a person of ordinary intelligence and prudence in the same situation as the defendant, not a person identical to the defendant placed in the same situation as the defendant.

1458601415253897221.text: Also worth noting: "A person who provokes an attack, whether by lawful or unlawful conduct, with intent to use such an attack as an excuse to cause death or great bodily harm to his or her assailant is not entitled to claim the privilege of self-defense."

1458601181161398274.text: 5/ This explains more of the cross-ex: did Rittenhouse provoke attackers? Were they about to kill or greatly harm him? Did he have any route of escape? Did he exhaust every means to avoid harm other than shooting. The prosecutor worked through these options.

1458600887010709508.text: 4/ Also, you can't argue self-defense if you provoked the attack UNLESS you reas believe you're about to be killed or subject to "great harm," BUT you still can't use deadly force unless you reas believe you've "exhausted every other reas means to escape or avoid death/great harm

1458599786152660994.text: 3/ This explains some of the questions asked of Rittenhouse on cross-ex today, for instance, about using a gun against someone who is unarmed.

1458599591922880513.text: You can only use the amount of force/threat you reasonably believe is needed to stop the threat you're defending yourself against. You can't intentionally use force that will cause death/great harm unless you reas believe it's necessary to prevent death/threat harm to yourself.

1458598517820338182.text: 1/ Before deliberation, the judge in the Rittenhouse case will instruct the jury on the law, incl' Wisconsin's self-defense law. A few key points: you can use force to stop "interference with your person" but there are limits on how much force you can use https://t.co/LGWQAWBJHB
